abstract.p: Angelo & Maxie's steakhouse chain will open franchise in Sixth Avenue in midrown Manhattan; restarateur Jerome O'Connor will open Half King pub on West 23rd Street in Manhattan; Patrick Fahey will open Sugar Lounge in downtown Manhattan in mid-September; Jean-Georges Vongerichten is consultant for Dune, high-end restaurant on Paradise Island in Bahamas; Hampton Chutney, which produces chutneys, will open downtown Manhattan branch; chef Waldy Malouf's Beacon restaurant will open branch in Stamford, Conn; Manhattan restarateur Marika Simerstein will open restaurant on West 70th Street in property that was formerly Mendy's West (M)

block.p: Steakhouses are proliferating in midtown, west of Rockefeller Center, with newcomers like Del Frisco's Double Eagle and Palm West. The latest addition is a branch of Angelo & Maxie's at 1285 Avenue of the Americas (52nd Street), which was designed, like the original in the Flatiron district, by Morris Nathanson.

Steakhouses are proliferating in midtown, west of Rockefeller Center, with newcomers like Del Frisco's Double Eagle and Palm West. The latest addition is a branch of Angelo & Maxie's at 1285 Avenue of the Americas (52nd Street), which was designed, like the original in the Flatiron district, by Morris Nathanson.
There are plenty of arts and crafts details and lots of cigars, some being sold in a shop where they are hand-rolled, and some being smoked in a downstairs dining room and bar with humidors.
Angelo & Maxie's is now part of the Chart House chain.

Jerome O'Connor, who owned St. Dymphnas on St. Mark's Place, has opened the Half King, a cozy pub at 505 West 23rd Street. It is decorated with weathered barn boards and has a bar with booths in one room, a lounge in another and even a little garden in the back.
His partners include Sebastian Junger, the author of ''The Perfect Storm,'' who was a regular at St. Dymphnas.
Next week, the Half King will start serving breakfast, lunch and dinner, with the menu featuring what Mr. O'Connor called upscale pub food. Swordfish, perhaps?

Thanks to Patrick Fahey's contacts in the movie business, Sugar, his lounge at 311 Church Street (Walker Street), which is to open in mid-September, will have such Hollywood backers as Matt Dillon, Kevin Dillon and David Keith. The decor will be Danish modern and the food will be served in bento boxes.
Jean-Georges Vongerichten is about to get his feet wet in the Caribbean. He is the consultant for Dune, a high-end restaurant to open Sept. 1 in the Ocean Club on Paradise Island in the Bahamas.
Hampton Chutney, a company that produces chutneys and has an Amagansett cafe that serves soft-filled flatbreads, will open a Manhattan branch at 68 Prince Street (Crosby Street) in the fall.
Beacon, the restaurant at 25 West 56th Street, where Waldy Malouf specializes in oven-roasted dishes, has opened a branch in Stamford, Conn., at 183 Harbor Drive.

Marika Somerstein, an owner of Water's Edge in Long Island City, Queens, and Donny Evans, who once owned Bridgehampton Cafe in Bridgehampton, N.Y., plan to open a restaurant at 208 West 70th Street, formerly Mendy's West, in the fall.
